facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 273 of 1963 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 273 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated July 15, 1955 of Madras High Court in Appeal Suit No. 142 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 15, 1955 of Madras High Court in Appeal Suit No. 142 of 1951.

facts.text: Tavazhi separated from tarwad on July 13, 1934 under a decree in a partition suit.

anchor.surface_text: originally it was a branch of a tarwad, but separated itself from the said tarwad on July 13, 1934 under a decree in a partition suit.

facts.text: Plaintiffs filed O.S. No. 108 of 1948 in Court of Subordinate Judge, Palghat against tavazhi for arrears of maintenance.

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiffs in O.S. No. 108 of 1948 in the Court of the Sub- ordinate Judge, Palghat, and the defendants in the said suit are members of a Malabar tavazhi ... The plaintiffs filed the suit against the tavazhi represented by its manager and others, for arrears of maintenance due to them and for other reliefs.

facts.text: Plaintiffs alleged Chalakkode nilam property was tavazhi property entitling them to maintenance from its income.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint it was alleged that the said Chalakkode nilam property was the property of the tavazhi and, therefore, they were entitled to maintenance from the income of the said property also.

facts.text: Defendants denied Chalakkode property is tavazhi property, alleged purchased from private funds of defendant 1 and her son defendant 4.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants in their written-statement denied that the said property was -the property of the tavazhi, but alleged that it was purchased from ,and out of the private funds of defendants 1 and her son, defendant 4.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held Chalakkode property is personal property of defendants 1 and 4, excluded its income from maintenance decree.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge held that the said property did number belong to the tavazhi but it was the personal property of defendants I and 4. In the result in giving a decree for maintenance, he did number take into companysideration the income from the said property.

facts.text: Madras High Court Division Bench held Chalakkode property belongs to tavazhi, remanded suit to Subordinate Judge for maintenance including its income.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, a Division Bench of the Madras High Court, having regard to the relevant presumptions under the Malabar law, held that the said property belonged to the tavazhi in the result, it allowed the appeal and remanded the suit to the Court of the Subordinate Judge for fixing the rate of maintenance after taking into account the income from the said property also.

facts.text: 4th defendant obtained certificate from High Court and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The 4th defendant, after obtaining- the certificate from the High Court, has preferred the present appeal to this Court against the judgment of the said -Court.

facts.text: Appellant and his mother are members of the tavazhi.

anchor.surface_text: whether a certain property, described as Chalakkode property, is the property of the Tavazhi of which the appellant and his mother are members or the separate property of the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Chalakkode property is tavazhi property.

anchor.surface_text: From the aforesaid facts we have numberhesitation in agreeing with the finding of the High Court that the said property was the property of the tavazhi.

anchor.surface_text: The assignment of the decree in execution whereof the said property was purchased was taken in favour of both defendants I and 4, the de jure and the de facto managers respectively.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 15, 1955 of Madras High Court in Appeal Suit No. 142 of 1951.

On appeal, a Division Bench of the Madras High Court, having regard to the relevant presumptions under the Malabar law, held that the said property belonged to the tavazhi in the result, it allowed the appeal and remanded the suit to the Court of the Subordinate Judge for fixing the rate of maintenance after taking into account the income from the said property also.

concepts.unlisted_description: Relevant presumptions under the Malabar law regarding property belonging to tavazhi

anchor.surface_text: Under Hindu law, when a property stands in the name of a member of a joint family, it is incumbent upon those asserting that it is a joint family property to establish it. When it is proved or admitted that a family possessed sufficient nucleus with the aid of which the member might have made the acquisition, the law raises a presumption that it is a joint family property and the onus is shifted to the individual member to establish that the property was acquired by him without the aid of the said nucleus.

concepts.interpretation: Distinguished from Marumakkathayam law; applies to joint Hindu family where nucleus shifts onus

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: overns a large section of people inhabiting the West Coast of South India. Marumakkathayam literally means descent through sisters children. There is

concepts.unlisted_description: Presumption of joint family property if sufficient nucleus exists, shifting onus to member claiming separate acquisition

anchor.surface_text: But the said principle has not been accepted or applied to acquisition of properties in the name of a junior member of a tarwad anandravan. It was held that there was no presumption either way and that the question had to be decided on the facts of each case see Govinda v. Nani 1 Dharnu Shetty Dejamma 2 Soopiadath Ahmad v. Mammad Kunhi 3 and Thatha Amma v. Thankappa.

concepts.interpretation: No presumption either way for junior member (anandravan) of tarwad; decided on facts

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: escendants, whether male or female, in the female line. But the descendants, whether male or female, of her sons or the sons of the said descendants i

Sekharan Nambiar 5 Soopidath Ahmad v. Mammad Kunhi 3 and Thatha Amma v. Thankappa. 4

concepts.unlisted_description: Strong presumption that property acquired in name of karnavan, karnavati, or tavazhi manager is family property unless rebutted by acceptable evidence

anchor.surface_text: A karnavati or karnavan is a representative of the tarwad or tavazhi and is the protector of the members thereof. He or she stands in a fiduciary relationship with the members thereof.

concepts.interpretation: Manager (de jure or de facto) stands in fiduciary relationship with tavazhi members; relevant to determining property ownership

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: pa.  4  His Lordship then discussed the oral and documentary evidence and proceeded We may at this s

concepts.unlisted_description: Karnavan or karnavati holds fiduciary relationship with family members

anchor.surface_text: A family governed by Marumakkathayam law is known as a tarwad it consists of a mother and her children, whether male or female, and all their descendants, whether male or female, in the female line. But the descendants, whether male or female, of her sons or the sons of the said descendants in the female line do number belong to the tarwad- they belong to the tarwads of their mothers.

concepts.unlisted_description: Family unit under Marumakkathayam law consisting of mother, children, and female-line descendants

anchor.surface_text: A tavazhi is a branch of a tarwad. It is comprised of a group of descendants in the female line of a female common ancestor who is a member of the tarwad. It is one of the units of the tarwad. It may own separate property as distinct from tarwad property.

concepts.unlisted_description: Branch of tarwad comprising female-line descendants of a female ancestor; may hold separate property
